trans-unit.source: RMS Protection with Windows Server File Classification Infrastructure (FCI)
trans-unit.target: RMS Protection with Windows Server File Classification Infrastructure (FCI)

trans-unit.source: Use this article for instructions and a script to use the Rights Management (RMS) client with the RMS Protection tool to configure File Server Resource Manager and file classification infrastructure (FCI).
trans-unit.target: Use this article for instructions and a script to use the Rights Management (RMS) client with the RMS Protection tool to configure File Server Resource Manager and file classification infrastructure (FCI).

trans-unit.source: This solutions lets you automatically protect all files in a folder on a file server running Windows Server, or automatically protect files that meet a specific criteria.
trans-unit.target: This solutions lets you automatically protect all files in a folder on a file server running Windows Server, or automatically protect files that meet a specific criteria.

trans-unit.source: For example, files that have been classified as containing confidential or sensitive information.
trans-unit.target: For example, files that have been classified as containing confidential or sensitive information.

trans-unit.source: This solution uses <link><linkText>Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link> (Azure RMS) to protect the files, so you must have this technology deployed in your organization.
trans-unit.target: This solution uses <link><linkText>Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link> (Azure RMS) to protect the files, so you must have this technology deployed in your organization.

trans-unit.source: Although Azure RMS includes a <link><linkText>connector</linkText><title></title></link> that supports file classification infrastructure, that solution supports native protection only—for example, Office files.
trans-unit.target: Although Azure RMS includes a <link><linkText>connector</linkText><title></title></link> that supports file classification infrastructure, that solution supports native protection only—for example, Office files.

trans-unit.source: To support all file types with file classification infrastructure, you must use the Windows PowerShell RMS Protection module, as documented in this article.
trans-unit.target: To support all file types with file classification infrastructure, you must use the Windows PowerShell RMS Protection module, as documented in this article.

trans-unit.source: The RMS Protection cmdlets, like the RMS sharing application, support generic protection as well as native protection, which means that all files can be protected.
trans-unit.target: The RMS Protection cmdlets, like the RMS sharing application, support generic protection as well as native protection, which means that all files can be protected.

trans-unit.source: For more information about these different protection levels, see the <link><linkText>Levels of protection – native and generic</linkText><title></title></link> section in the <link><linkText>Rights Management sharing application administrator guide</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about these different protection levels, see the <link><linkText>Levels of protection – native and generic</linkText><title></title></link> section in the <link><linkText>Rights Management sharing application administrator guide</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The instructions that follow are for Windows Server 2012 R2 or Windows Server 2012.
trans-unit.target: The instructions that follow are for Windows Server 2012 R2 or Windows Server 2012.

trans-unit.source: If you run other supported versions of Windows, you might need to adapt some of the steps for differences between your operating system version and the one documented in this article.
trans-unit.target: If you run other supported versions of Windows, you might need to adapt some of the steps for differences between your operating system version and the one documented in this article.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites for Azure RMS protection with Windows Server FCI
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites for Azure RMS protection with Windows Server FCI

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites for these instructions:
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites for these instructions:

trans-unit.source: On each file server where you will run File Resource Manager with file classification infrastructure:
trans-unit.target: On each file server where you will run File Resource Manager with file classification infrastructure:

trans-unit.source: You have installed File Server Resource Manager as one of the role services for the File Services role.
trans-unit.target: You have installed File Server Resource Manager as one of the role services for the File Services role.

trans-unit.source: You have identified a local folder that contains files to protect with Rights Management.
trans-unit.target: You have identified a local folder that contains files to protect with Rights Management.

trans-unit.source: For example, C:\FileShare.
trans-unit.target: For example, C:\FileShare.

trans-unit.source: You have installed the RMS Protection tool, including the prerequisites for the tool (such as the RMS client) and for Azure RMS (such as the service principal account).
trans-unit.target: You have installed the RMS Protection tool, including the prerequisites for the tool (such as the RMS client) and for Azure RMS (such as the service principal account).

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>RMS Protection Cmdlets</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>RMS Protection Cmdlets</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to change the default level of RMS protection (native or generic) for specific file name extensions, you have edited the registry as described in the <link><linkText>File API configuration</linkText><title></title></link> page.
trans-unit.target: If you want to change the default level of RMS protection (native or generic) for specific file name extensions, you have edited the registry as described in the <link><linkText>File API configuration</linkText><title></title></link> page.

trans-unit.source: You have an Internet connection, with configured computer settings if required for a proxy server.
trans-unit.target: You have an Internet connection, with configured computer settings if required for a proxy server.

trans-unit.source: For example: netsh winhttp import proxy source=ie
trans-unit.target: For example: netsh winhttp import proxy source=ie

trans-unit.source: You have configured the additional prerequisites for your Azure Rights Management deployment, as described in <link><linkText>about_RMSProtection_AzureRMS</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You have configured the additional prerequisites for your Azure Rights Management deployment, as described in <link><linkText>about_RMSProtection_AzureRMS</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Specifically, you have the following values to connect to Azure RMS by using a service principal:
trans-unit.target: Specifically, you have the following values to connect to Azure RMS by using a service principal:

trans-unit.source: BposTenantId
trans-unit.target: BposTenantId

trans-unit.source: AppPrincipalId
trans-unit.target: AppPrincipalId

trans-unit.source: Symmetric key
trans-unit.target: Symmetric key

trans-unit.source: You have synchronized your on-premises Active Directory user accounts with Azure Active Directory or Office 365, including their email address.
trans-unit.target: You have synchronized your on-premises Active Directory user accounts with Azure Active Directory or Office 365, including their email address.

trans-unit.source: This is required for all users that might need to access files after they are protected by FCI and Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: This is required for all users that might need to access files after they are protected by FCI and Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: If you do not do this step (for example, in a test environment), users might be blocked from accessing these files.
trans-unit.target: If you do not do this step (for example, in a test environment), users might be blocked from accessing these files.

trans-unit.source: If you need more information about this account configuration, see <link><linkText>Preparing for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you need more information about this account configuration, see <link><linkText>Preparing for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You have identified the Rights Management template to use, which will protect the files.
trans-unit.target: You have identified the Rights Management template to use, which will protect the files.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that you know the ID for this template by using the <link><linkText>Get-RMSTemplate</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that you know the ID for this template by using the <link><linkText>Get-RMSTemplate</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Instructions to configure File Server Resource Manager FCI for Azure RMS protection
trans-unit.target: Instructions to configure File Server Resource Manager FCI for Azure RMS protection

trans-unit.source: Follow these instructions to automatically protect all files in a folder, by using a Windows PowerShell script as a custom task.
trans-unit.target: Follow these instructions to automatically protect all files in a folder, by using a Windows PowerShell script as a custom task.

trans-unit.source: Do these procedures in this order:
trans-unit.target: Do these procedures in this order:

trans-unit.source: Save the Windows PowerShell script
trans-unit.target: Save the Windows PowerShell script

trans-unit.source: Create a classification property for Rights Management (RMS)
trans-unit.target: Create a classification property for Rights Management (RMS)

trans-unit.source: Create a classification rule (Classify for RMS)
trans-unit.target: Create a classification rule (Classify for RMS)

trans-unit.source: Configure the classification schedule
trans-unit.target: Configure the classification schedule

trans-unit.source: Create a custom file management task (Protect files with RMS)
trans-unit.target: Create a custom file management task (Protect files with RMS)

trans-unit.source: Test the configuration by manually running the rule and task
trans-unit.target: Test the configuration by manually running the rule and task

trans-unit.source: At the end of these instructions, all files in your selected folder will be classified with the custom property of RMS, and these files will then be protected by Rights Management.
trans-unit.target: At the end of these instructions, all files in your selected folder will be classified with the custom property of RMS, and these files will then be protected by Rights Management.

trans-unit.source: For a more complex configuration that selectively protects some files and not others, you can then create or use a different classification property and rule, with a file management task that protects just those files.
trans-unit.target: For a more complex configuration that selectively protects some files and not others, you can then create or use a different classification property and rule, with a file management task that protects just those files.

trans-unit.source: Save the Windows PowerShell script
trans-unit.target: Save the Windows PowerShell script

trans-unit.source: Expand the <link><linkText>Windows PowerShell Script for Azure RMS protection by using File Server Resource Manager FCI</linkText><title></title></link> section in this article, and copy its contents.
trans-unit.target: Expand the <link><linkText>Windows PowerShell Script for Azure RMS protection by using File Server Resource Manager FCI</linkText><title></title></link> section in this article, and copy its contents.

trans-unit.source: Paste the contents of the script and name the file RMS-Protect-FCI.ps1 on your own computer.
trans-unit.target: Paste the contents of the script and name the file RMS-Protect-FCI.ps1 on your own computer.

trans-unit.source: Review the script and make the following changes:
trans-unit.target: Review the script and make the following changes:

trans-unit.source: Search for the following string and replace it with your own AppPrincipalId that you use with the <link><linkText>Set-RMSServerAuthentication</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to connect to Azure RMS:
trans-unit.target: Search for the following string and replace it with your own AppPrincipalId that you use with the <link><linkText>Set-RMSServerAuthentication</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to connect to Azure RMS:

trans-unit.source: For example, the script might look like this:
trans-unit.target: For example, the script might look like this:

trans-unit.source: [Parameter(Mandatory = $false)]
trans-unit.target: [Parameter(Mandatory = $false)]

trans-unit.source: [Parameter(Mandatory = $false)] [string]$AppPrincipalId = "b5e3f76a-b5c2-4c96-a594-a0807f65bba4",
trans-unit.target: [Parameter(Mandatory = $false)] [string]$AppPrincipalId = "b5e3f76a-b5c2-4c96-a594-a0807f65bba4",

trans-unit.source: Search for the following string and replace it with your own symmetric key that you use with the <link><linkText>Set-RMSServerAuthentication</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to connect to Azure RMS:
trans-unit.target: Search for the following string and replace it with your own symmetric key that you use with the <link><linkText>Set-RMSServerAuthentication</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to connect to Azure RMS:

trans-unit.source: For example, the script might look like this:
trans-unit.target: For example, the script might look like this:

trans-unit.source: [Parameter(Mandatory = $false)]
trans-unit.target: [Parameter(Mandatory = $false)]

trans-unit.source: [string]$SymmetricKey = "zIeMu8zNJ6U377CLtppkhkbl4gjodmYSXUVwAO5ycgA="
trans-unit.target: [string]$SymmetricKey = "zIeMu8zNJ6U377CLtppkhkbl4gjodmYSXUVwAO5ycgA="

trans-unit.source: Search for the following string and replace it with your own BposTenantId (tenant ID) that you use with the <link><linkText>Set-RMSServerAuthentication</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to connect to Azure RMS:
trans-unit.target: Search for the following string and replace it with your own BposTenantId (tenant ID) that you use with the <link><linkText>Set-RMSServerAuthentication</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to connect to Azure RMS:

trans-unit.source: For example, the script might look like this:
trans-unit.target: For example, the script might look like this:

trans-unit.source: [Parameter(Mandatory = $false)]
trans-unit.target: [Parameter(Mandatory = $false)]

trans-unit.source: [string]$BposTenantId = "23976bc6-dcd4-4173-9d96-dad1f48efd42",
trans-unit.target: [string]$BposTenantId = "23976bc6-dcd4-4173-9d96-dad1f48efd42",

trans-unit.source: If your server is running Windows Server 2012, you might have to manually load the RMSProtection module at the beginning of the script.
trans-unit.target: If your server is running Windows Server 2012, you might have to manually load the RMSProtection module at the beginning of the script.

trans-unit.source: Add the following command (or equivalent if the "Program Files" folder is on a drive other than the C: drive :
trans-unit.target: Add the following command (or equivalent if the "Program Files" folder is on a drive other than the C: drive :

trans-unit.source: Sign the script.
trans-unit.target: Sign the script.

trans-unit.source: If you do not sign the script (more secure), you must configure Windows PowerShell on the servers that run it.
trans-unit.target: If you do not sign the script (more secure), you must configure Windows PowerShell on the servers that run it.

trans-unit.source: For example, run a Windows PowerShell session with the Run as Administrator option, and type: Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted.
trans-unit.target: For example, run a Windows PowerShell session with the Run as Administrator option, and type: Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted.

trans-unit.source: However, this configuration lets all unsigned scripts run (less secure).
trans-unit.target: However, this configuration lets all unsigned scripts run (less secure).

trans-unit.source: For more information about signing Windows PowerShell scripts, see <link><linkText>about_Signing</linkText><title></title></link> in the PowerShell documentation library.
trans-unit.target: For more information about signing Windows PowerShell scripts, see <link><linkText>about_Signing</linkText><title></title></link> in the PowerShell documentation library.

trans-unit.source: Save the file locally on each file server that will run File Resource Manager with file classification infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: Save the file locally on each file server that will run File Resource Manager with file classification infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: For example, save the file in C:\RMS-Protection.
trans-unit.target: For example, save the file in C:\RMS-Protection.

trans-unit.source: Secure this file by using NTFS permissions so that unauthorized users cannot modify it.
trans-unit.target: Secure this file by using NTFS permissions so that unauthorized users cannot modify it.

trans-unit.source: You're now ready to start configuring File Server Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: You're now ready to start configuring File Server Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: Create a classification property for Rights Management (RMS)
trans-unit.target: Create a classification property for Rights Management (RMS)

trans-unit.source: In File Server Resource Manager, Classification Management, create a new local property:
trans-unit.target: In File Server Resource Manager, Classification Management, create a new local property:

trans-unit.source: Name: Type RMS
trans-unit.target: Name: Type RMS

trans-unit.source: Description: Type Rights Management protection
trans-unit.target: Description: Type Rights Management protection

trans-unit.source: Property Type: Select Yes/No
trans-unit.target: Property Type: Select Yes/No

trans-unit.source: Value: Select Yes
trans-unit.target: Value: Select Yes

trans-unit.source: We can now create a classification rule that uses this property.
trans-unit.target: We can now create a classification rule that uses this property.

trans-unit.source: Create a classification rule (Classify for RMS)
trans-unit.target: Create a classification rule (Classify for RMS)

trans-unit.source: Create a new classification rule:
trans-unit.target: Create a new classification rule:

trans-unit.source: On the General tab:
trans-unit.target: On the General tab:

trans-unit.source: Name: Type Classify for RMS
trans-unit.target: Name: Type Classify for RMS

trans-unit.source: Enabled: Keep the default, which is that this checkbox is selected.
trans-unit.target: Enabled: Keep the default, which is that this checkbox is selected.

trans-unit.source: Description: Type Classify all files in the folder for Rights Management.
trans-unit.target: Description: Type Classify all files in the folder for Rights Management.

trans-unit.source: Replace with your chosen folder name.
trans-unit.target: Replace with your chosen folder name.

trans-unit.source: For example, Classify all files in the C:\FileShare folder for Rights Management
trans-unit.target: For example, Classify all files in the C:\FileShare folder for Rights Management

trans-unit.source: Scope: Add your chosen folder.
trans-unit.target: Scope: Add your chosen folder.

trans-unit.source: For example, C:\FileShare.
trans-unit.target: For example, C:\FileShare.

trans-unit.source: Do not select the checkboxes.
trans-unit.target: Do not select the checkboxes.

trans-unit.source: On the Classification tab:
trans-unit.target: On the Classification tab:

trans-unit.source: Classification method: Select Folder Classifier
trans-unit.target: Classification method: Select Folder Classifier

trans-unit.source: Property name: Select RMS
trans-unit.target: Property name: Select RMS

trans-unit.source: Property value: Select Yes
trans-unit.target: Property value: Select Yes

trans-unit.source: Although you can run the classification rules manually, for ongoing operations, you will want this rule to run on a schedule so that new files will be classified with the RMS property.
trans-unit.target: Although you can run the classification rules manually, for ongoing operations, you will want this rule to run on a schedule so that new files will be classified with the RMS property.

trans-unit.source: Configure the classification schedule
trans-unit.target: Configure the classification schedule

trans-unit.source: On the Automatic Classification tab:
trans-unit.target: On the Automatic Classification tab:

trans-unit.source: Enable fixed schedule: Select this checkbox.
trans-unit.target: Enable fixed schedule: Select this checkbox.

trans-unit.source: Configure the schedule for all classification rules to run, which includes our new rule to classify files with the RMS property.
trans-unit.target: Configure the schedule for all classification rules to run, which includes our new rule to classify files with the RMS property.

trans-unit.source: Allow continuous classification for new files: Select this checkbox so that new files will be classified.
trans-unit.target: Allow continuous classification for new files: Select this checkbox so that new files will be classified.

trans-unit.source: Optional: Make any other changes that you want, such as configuring options for reports and notifications.
trans-unit.target: Optional: Make any other changes that you want, such as configuring options for reports and notifications.

trans-unit.source: Now you've completed the classification configuration, you're ready to configure a management task to apply the RMS protection to the files.
trans-unit.target: Now you've completed the classification configuration, you're ready to configure a management task to apply the RMS protection to the files.

trans-unit.source: Create a custom file management task (Protect files with RMS)
trans-unit.target: Create a custom file management task (Protect files with RMS)

trans-unit.source: In File Management Tasks, create a new file management task:
trans-unit.target: In File Management Tasks, create a new file management task:

trans-unit.source: On the General tab:
trans-unit.target: On the General tab:

trans-unit.source: Task name: Type Protect files with RMS
trans-unit.target: Task name: Type Protect files with RMS

trans-unit.source: Keep the Enable checkbox selected.
trans-unit.target: Keep the Enable checkbox selected.

trans-unit.source: Description: Type Protect files in with Rights Management and a template by using a Windows PowerShell script.
trans-unit.target: Description: Type Protect files in with Rights Management and a template by using a Windows PowerShell script.

trans-unit.source: Replace with your chosen folder name.
trans-unit.target: Replace with your chosen folder name.

trans-unit.source: For example, Protect files in C:\FileShare with Rights Management and a template by using a Windows PowerShell script
trans-unit.target: For example, Protect files in C:\FileShare with Rights Management and a template by using a Windows PowerShell script

trans-unit.source: Scope: Select your chosen folder.
trans-unit.target: Scope: Select your chosen folder.

trans-unit.source: For example, C:\FileShare.
trans-unit.target: For example, C:\FileShare.

trans-unit.source: Do not select the checkboxes.
trans-unit.target: Do not select the checkboxes.

trans-unit.source: On the Action tab:
trans-unit.target: On the Action tab:

trans-unit.source: Type: Select Custom
trans-unit.target: Type: Select Custom

trans-unit.source: Executable: Specify the following:
trans-unit.target: Executable: Specify the following:

trans-unit.source: If Windows is not on your C: drive, modify this path or browse to this file.
trans-unit.target: If Windows is not on your C: drive, modify this path or browse to this file.

trans-unit.source: Argument: Specify the following, supplying your own values for and
trans-unit.target: Argument: Specify the following, supplying your own values for and

trans-unit.source: For example, if you copied the script to C:\RMS-Protection and the template ID you identified from the prerequisites is e6ee2481-26b9-45e5-b34a-f744eacd53b0, specify the following:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you copied the script to C:\RMS-Protection and the template ID you identified from the prerequisites is e6ee2481-26b9-45e5-b34a-f744eacd53b0, specify the following:

trans-unit.source: -Noprofile -Command "C:\RMS-Protection\RMS-Protect-FCI.ps1 -File '[Source File Path]' -TemplateID e6ee2481-26b9-45e5-b34a-f744eacd53b0 -OwnerMail [Source File Owner Email]"
trans-unit.target: -Noprofile -Command "C:\RMS-Protection\RMS-Protect-FCI.ps1 -File '[Source File Path]' -TemplateID e6ee2481-26b9-45e5-b34a-f744eacd53b0 -OwnerMail [Source File Owner Email]"

trans-unit.source: In this command, [Source File Path] and [Source File Owner Email] are both FCI-specific variables, so type these exactly as they appear in the command above.
trans-unit.target: In this command, [Source File Path] and [Source File Owner Email] are both FCI-specific variables, so type these exactly as they appear in the command above.

trans-unit.source: The first one is used by FCI to automatically specify the identified file in the folder, and the second is for FCI to automatically retrieve the email address of the named Owner of the identified file.
trans-unit.target: The first one is used by FCI to automatically specify the identified file in the folder, and the second is for FCI to automatically retrieve the email address of the named Owner of the identified file.

trans-unit.source: This command is repeated for each file in the folder, which in our example, is each file in the C:\FileShare folder that additionally, has RMS as a file classification property.
trans-unit.target: This command is repeated for each file in the folder, which in our example, is each file in the C:\FileShare folder that additionally, has RMS as a file classification property.

trans-unit.source: The -OwnerMail [Source File Owner Email] parameter and value ensures that the original owner of the file is granted the Rights Management owner of the file after it is protected.
trans-unit.target: The -OwnerMail [Source File Owner Email] parameter and value ensures that the original owner of the file is granted the Rights Management owner of the file after it is protected.

trans-unit.source: This ensures that the original file owner has all Rights Management rights to their own files.
trans-unit.target: This ensures that the original file owner has all Rights Management rights to their own files.

trans-unit.source: When files are created by a domain user, the email address is automatically retrieved from Active Directory by using the user account name in the file's Owner property.
trans-unit.target: When files are created by a domain user, the email address is automatically retrieved from Active Directory by using the user account name in the file's Owner property.

trans-unit.source: To do this, the file server must be in the same domain or trusted domain as the user.
trans-unit.target: To do this, the file server must be in the same domain or trusted domain as the user.

trans-unit.source: Whenever possible, assign the original owners to protected documents, to ensure that these users continue to have full control over the files that they created.
trans-unit.target: Whenever possible, assign the original owners to protected documents, to ensure that these users continue to have full control over the files that they created.

trans-unit.source: However, if you use the [Source File Owner Email] variable as above, and a file does not have a domain user defined as the owner (for example, a local account was used to create the file, so the owner displays SYSTEM), the script will fail.
trans-unit.target: However, if you use the [Source File Owner Email] variable as above, and a file does not have a domain user defined as the owner (for example, a local account was used to create the file, so the owner displays SYSTEM), the script will fail.

trans-unit.source: For files that do not have a domain user as owner, you can either copy and save these files yourself as a domain user, so that you become the owner for just these files.
trans-unit.target: For files that do not have a domain user as owner, you can either copy and save these files yourself as a domain user, so that you become the owner for just these files.

trans-unit.source: Or, if you have permissions, you can manually change the owner.
trans-unit.target: Or, if you have permissions, you can manually change the owner.

trans-unit.source: Or alternatively, you can supply a specific email address (such as your own or a group address for the IT department) instead of the [Source File Owner Email] variable, which means that all files you protect by using this script will use this email address to define the new owner.
trans-unit.target: Or alternatively, you can supply a specific email address (such as your own or a group address for the IT department) instead of the [Source File Owner Email] variable, which means that all files you protect by using this script will use this email address to define the new owner.

trans-unit.source: Run the command as: Select Local System
trans-unit.target: Run the command as: Select Local System

trans-unit.source: On the Condition tab:
trans-unit.target: On the Condition tab:

trans-unit.source: Property: Select RMS
trans-unit.target: Property: Select RMS

trans-unit.source: Operator: Select Equal
trans-unit.target: Operator: Select Equal

trans-unit.source: Value: Select Yes
trans-unit.target: Value: Select Yes

trans-unit.source: On the Schedule tab:
trans-unit.target: On the Schedule tab:

trans-unit.source: Run at: Configure your preferred schedule.
trans-unit.target: Run at: Configure your preferred schedule.

trans-unit.source: Allow plenty of time for the script to complete.
trans-unit.target: Allow plenty of time for the script to complete.

trans-unit.source: Although this solution protects all files in the folder, the script runs once for each file, each time.
trans-unit.target: Although this solution protects all files in the folder, the script runs once for each file, each time.

trans-unit.source: Although this takes longer than protecting all the files at the same time, which the RMS Protection tool supports, this file-by-file configuration for FCI is more powerful.
trans-unit.target: Although this takes longer than protecting all the files at the same time, which the RMS Protection tool supports, this file-by-file configuration for FCI is more powerful.

trans-unit.source: For example, the protected files can have different owners (retain the original owner) when you use the [Source File Owner Email] variable, and this file-by-file action will be required if you later change the configuration to selectively protect files rather than all files in a folder.
trans-unit.target: For example, the protected files can have different owners (retain the original owner) when you use the [Source File Owner Email] variable, and this file-by-file action will be required if you later change the configuration to selectively protect files rather than all files in a folder.

trans-unit.source: Run continuously on new files: Select this checkbox.
trans-unit.target: Run continuously on new files: Select this checkbox.

trans-unit.source: Test the configuration by manually running the rule and task
trans-unit.target: Test the configuration by manually running the rule and task

trans-unit.source: Run the classification rule:
trans-unit.target: Run the classification rule:

trans-unit.source: Click Classification Rules > Run Classification With All Rules Now
trans-unit.target: Click Classification Rules > Run Classification With All Rules Now

trans-unit.source: Click Wait for classification to complete, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click Wait for classification to complete, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Wait for the Running Classification dialog box to close and then view the results in the automatically displayed report.
trans-unit.target: Wait for the Running Classification dialog box to close and then view the results in the automatically displayed report.

trans-unit.source: You should see 1 for the Properties field and the number of files in your folder.
trans-unit.target: You should see 1 for the Properties field and the number of files in your folder.

trans-unit.source: Confirm by using File Explorer and checking the properties of files in your chosen folder.
trans-unit.target: Confirm by using File Explorer and checking the properties of files in your chosen folder.

trans-unit.source: On the Classification tab, you should see RMS as a property name and Yes for its Value.
trans-unit.target: On the Classification tab, you should see RMS as a property name and Yes for its Value.

trans-unit.source: Run the file management task:
trans-unit.target: Run the file management task:

trans-unit.source: Click File Management Tasks > Protect files with RMS > Run File Management Task Now
trans-unit.target: Click File Management Tasks > Protect files with RMS > Run File Management Task Now

trans-unit.source: Click Wait for the task to complete, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click Wait for the task to complete, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Wait for the Running File Management Task dialog box to close and then view the results in the automatically displayed report.
trans-unit.target: Wait for the Running File Management Task dialog box to close and then view the results in the automatically displayed report.

trans-unit.source: You should see the number of files that are in your chosen folder in the Files field.
trans-unit.target: You should see the number of files that are in your chosen folder in the Files field.

trans-unit.source: Confirm that the files in your chosen folder are now protected by RMS.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that the files in your chosen folder are now protected by RMS.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your chosen folder is C:\FileShare, type the following in a Windows PowerShell session and confirm that no files have a status of UnProtected:
trans-unit.target: For example, if your chosen folder is C:\FileShare, type the following in a Windows PowerShell session and confirm that no files have a status of UnProtected:

trans-unit.source: Some troubleshooting tips:
trans-unit.target: Some troubleshooting tips:

trans-unit.source: - If you see 0 in the report, instead of the number of files in your folder, this indicates that the script did not run.
trans-unit.target: - If you see 0 in the report, instead of the number of files in your folder, this indicates that the script did not run.

trans-unit.source: First, check the script itself by loading it in Windows PowerShell ISE to validate the script contents and try running it to see if any errors are displayed.
trans-unit.target: First, check the script itself by loading it in Windows PowerShell ISE to validate the script contents and try running it to see if any errors are displayed.

trans-unit.source: With no arguments specified, the script will try to connect and authenticate to Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: With no arguments specified, the script will try to connect and authenticate to Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: - If the script reports that it couldn't connect to Azure RMS, check the values it displays for the service principal account, which you specified in the script.
trans-unit.target: - If the script reports that it couldn't connect to Azure RMS, check the values it displays for the service principal account, which you specified in the script.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to create this service principal account, see the second prerequisite in <link><linkText>about_RMSProtection_AzureRMS</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to create this service principal account, see the second prerequisite in <link><linkText>about_RMSProtection_AzureRMS</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: - If the script reports that it could connect to Azure RMS and your Azure region is outside North America, check that you have edited the registry correctly for this configuration.
trans-unit.target: - If the script reports that it could connect to Azure RMS and your Azure region is outside North America, check that you have edited the registry correctly for this configuration.

trans-unit.source: A good test for this is to run Get-RMSTemplate directly from Windows PowerShell on the server.
trans-unit.target: A good test for this is to run Get-RMSTemplate directly from Windows PowerShell on the server.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the registry edits, see the third prerequisite in <link><linkText>about_RMSProtection_AzureRMS</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about the registry edits, see the third prerequisite in <link><linkText>about_RMSProtection_AzureRMS</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: - If the script by itself runs in Windows PowerShell ISE without errors, try running it as follows from a PowerShell session, specifying a file name to protect and without the -OwnerEmail parameter:
trans-unit.target: - If the script by itself runs in Windows PowerShell ISE without errors, try running it as follows from a PowerShell session, specifying a file name to protect and without the -OwnerEmail parameter:

trans-unit.source: powershell.exe -Noprofile -Command "<html></html>\RMS-Protect-FCI.ps1 -File <html></html>' -TemplateID <html></html>"
trans-unit.target: powershell.exe -Noprofile -Command "<html></html>\RMS-Protect-FCI.ps1 -File <html></html>' -TemplateID <html></html>"

trans-unit.source: - If the script runs successfully in this Windows PowerShell session, check your entries for Executive and Argument in the file management task action.
trans-unit.target: - If the script runs successfully in this Windows PowerShell session, check your entries for Executive and Argument in the file management task action.

trans-unit.source: If you have specified -OwnerEmail [Source File Owner Email], try removing this parameter.
trans-unit.target: If you have specified -OwnerEmail [Source File Owner Email], try removing this parameter.

trans-unit.source: If the file management task works successfully without -OwnerEmail [Source File Owner Email], check that the unprotected files have a domain user listed as the file owner, rather than SYSTEM.
trans-unit.target: If the file management task works successfully without -OwnerEmail [Source File Owner Email], check that the unprotected files have a domain user listed as the file owner, rather than SYSTEM.

trans-unit.source: To do this, use the Security tab for the file's properties, and then click Advanced.
trans-unit.target: To do this, use the Security tab for the file's properties, and then click Advanced.

trans-unit.source: The Owner value is displayed immediately after the file Name.
trans-unit.target: The Owner value is displayed immediately after the file Name.

trans-unit.source: Also, verify that the file server is in the same domain or a trusted domain to lookup the user's email address from Active Directory Domain Services.
trans-unit.target: Also, verify that the file server is in the same domain or a trusted domain to lookup the user's email address from Active Directory Domain Services.

trans-unit.source: - If you see the correct number of files in the report but the files are not protected, try protecting the files manually by using the <link><linkText>Protect-RMSFile</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet, to see if any errors are displayed.
trans-unit.target: - If you see the correct number of files in the report but the files are not protected, try protecting the files manually by using the <link><linkText>Protect-RMSFile</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet, to see if any errors are displayed.

trans-unit.source: When you have confirmed that these tasks run successfully, you can close File Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: When you have confirmed that these tasks run successfully, you can close File Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: New files will be automatically protected and all files will be protected again when the schedules run.
trans-unit.target: New files will be automatically protected and all files will be protected again when the schedules run.

trans-unit.source: Re-protecting files ensures that any changes to the template are applied to the files.
trans-unit.target: Re-protecting files ensures that any changes to the template are applied to the files.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Windows PowerShell Script for Azure RMS protection by using File Server Resource Manager FCI
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Windows PowerShell Script for Azure RMS protection by using File Server Resource Manager FCI

trans-unit.source: This section contains the sample script to copy and edit, as described in the preceding section.
trans-unit.target: This section contains the sample script to copy and edit, as described in the preceding section.

trans-unit.source: ***Disclaimer**: This sample script is not supported under any Microsoft standard support program or service.
trans-unit.target: ***Disclaimer**: This sample script is not supported under any Microsoft standard support program or service.

trans-unit.source: This sample*
trans-unit.target: This sample*

trans-unit.source: script is provided AS IS without warranty of any kind.
trans-unit.target: script is provided AS IS without warranty of any kind.

trans-unit.source: Modifying the instructions to selectively protect files
trans-unit.target: Modifying the instructions to selectively protect files

trans-unit.source: When you have the preceding instructions working, it's then very easy to modify them for a more sophisticated configuration.
trans-unit.target: When you have the preceding instructions working, it's then very easy to modify them for a more sophisticated configuration.

trans-unit.source: For example, protect files by using the same script but only for files that contain personal identifiable information, and perhaps select a template that has more restrictive rights.
trans-unit.target: For example, protect files by using the same script but only for files that contain personal identifiable information, and perhaps select a template that has more restrictive rights.

trans-unit.source: To do this, use one of the built-in classification properties (for example, Personally Identifiable Information) or create your own new property.
trans-unit.target: To do this, use one of the built-in classification properties (for example, Personally Identifiable Information) or create your own new property.

trans-unit.source: Then create a new rule that uses this property.
trans-unit.target: Then create a new rule that uses this property.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might select the Content Classifier, choose the Personally Identifiable Information property with a value of High, and configure the string or expression pattern that identifies the file to be configured for this property (such as the string "Date of Birth").
trans-unit.target: For example, you might select the Content Classifier, choose the Personally Identifiable Information property with a value of High, and configure the string or expression pattern that identifies the file to be configured for this property (such as the string "Date of Birth").

trans-unit.source: Now all you need to do is create a new file management task that uses the same script but perhaps with a different template, and configure the condition for the classification property that you have just configured.
trans-unit.target: Now all you need to do is create a new file management task that uses the same script but perhaps with a different template, and configure the condition for the classification property that you have just configured.

trans-unit.source: For example, instead of the condition that we configured previously (RMS property, Equal, Yes), select the Personally Identifiable Information property with the Operator value set to Equal and the Value of High.
trans-unit.target: For example, instead of the condition that we configured previously (RMS property, Equal, Yes), select the Personally Identifiable Information property with the Operator value set to Equal and the Value of High.
